resources.string: Housed in the very industrial hall that was used by Oskar Schindler as an enamel plant back in WWII, this is surely one of the most fascinating museums in Krakow.
Test tubes and dust-caked glass bottles of all shapes and sizes are crammed into the various historic pharmacy rooms of this interesting and quirky little museum.
The Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum is perhaps the most sobering of all the WWII relics in Europe.

Set beneath the cobbles of the Main Market Square, the Rynek Underground Museum offers a journey back in time; back to when merchants from all over Slavic Europe would have traded cloth and wares in this sprawling plaza in the heart of the town.
Just a glimpse at the swish, Bauhaus-style shell of the MOCAK museum in Podgorze is enough to hint at the wonders that lurk within.
Haunting ghosts and spine-tingling ghouls await visitors to this spooky museum on Florianska Street.
Café Oranzeria restaurant is located on the top floor of the four star Hotel Kossak.
The sunny and serene interior allows a breath of fresh air compared to cluttered, murky venues in the Old Town.
Augustiańska 3 is just the address to go when you\'re in for both a healthy snack and a satisfying meal.
The place’s philosophy is to appreciate the sweetness of doing nothing.
A sort of couchsurfing for food lovers, Eataway is a new idea to bring home cooks and guests together, providing a refreshing alternative to either eating at home or eating at a restaurant.
MoaBurger is a family business created out of passion for good food. We serve the best quality meat and the freshest possible ingredients available on the market.

Starka Restaurant is famed in these parts not only for their sumptuous Polish cuisine, but also for their head-spinning brand of vodkas, such as cranberry or ginger flavour, concocted on these very premises.
A nice amalgamation of classic Irish pub and Cracovian cellar bar.
The word is out on this pseudo-speakeasy, and now that they\'ve normalised their opening hours we're lifting the veil on the best cocktail bar in Kraków.

Opening in the formerly abandoned, monstrous and much-maligned Soviet-era Forum Hotel, Forum Przestrzenie immediately vaults itself to the top of the list of Kraków\'s most original, intriguing and hip locales
Though looking like a downtrodden dive bar in the midst of the drunken late night din, Tram Bar actually serves as a sophisticated escape from the shenanigans taking place just beyond its door.
Sit back enjoying your cocktail or beer overlooking the market square and Cloth Hall from Hard Rock’s modern split-level bar.
Le Scandale unfolds over a series of sleek rooms draped with sultry ladies and sharp-dressed business sharks, before revealing an enormous garden (heated in winter) in the back.
As the name implies, Mojito Caffé marries coffee culture with craft cocktails - and quite literally in the form of their exciting coffee cocktails, which are a great way to get the night rolling.
An Indian-owned den of oriental exotica, Shisha Club\'s cup runneth over with draped fabrics, oriental rugs, stained glass lanterns, colourful cushions and intricate tiles.
It\'s a modern boutique hotel with 60 rooms and three restaurants, and also boasts a state of the art conference room for business guests.
Although a brand new arrival on the Cracow hotel scene, Sheraton has managed to acquire what is arguably the best location in town.
This modern, yet homely, locale makes for an excellent choice for couples looking for a Krakow apartment for the weekend (or longer!).
Poland was the toast of Paris\'s pre-war international exhibition, winning more prizes than any other country.
Copernicus is considered the premier Krakow hotel, with an outstanding restaurant and service throughout that\'s second to none.
The Zamek Korzkiew is located in picturesque countryside just outside Cracow, and the interiors have been tastefully renovated to combine Old World style with modern convenience.
